[Fred Dello Russo]: new features that one finds in parks in the United States today, which also benefit from federal funding.

[Fred Dello Russo]: 18-062, offered by President Caraviello.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Be it resolved the Medford City Council request that the Mayor and City Solicitor look into joining the lawsuit that other cities have joined against the pharmaceutical companies that have flooded the city with opioids.

[Fred Dello Russo]: One of the major outcomes of such large interest and involvement in battling the opioid crisis in our nation is the coming to light of the fact that

[Fred Dello Russo]: The pharmaceutical companies presented false information to the medical community regarding the addictiveness of these drugs.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And where they were prescribed en masse in the mid to late 1990s resulted in a lot of the addictive cycles that we've seen develop in society.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And so, Mr. President, this is great leadership as usual.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The mayor had appointed me some months ago, weeks ago, to represent, to be one of the representatives of the community to the ongoing Green Line Extension Project.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The project is entering a new phase.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They're due to begin construction in the near future.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This will be a process that I think will unfold over the next two years as far as working on the station, the tracks, the rail beds.

[Fred Dello Russo]: In many ways, construction and pre-construction has already begun.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We met with the project manager from the MBTA, the assistant manager and many of the community outreach people, and representatives from Medford, Somerville, Cambridge, and related constituencies.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'll continue to keep the community up to date, and I'm going to continue to urge the mayor

[Fred Dello Russo]: to find resources available on behalf of the administration and the citizens of the community, to have trained representatives and people who are adept at development and planning issues at the table with us.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This is going to be a project

[Fred Dello Russo]: Lal Ruma, who is a citizen and a biter to the tracks, has been active for nearly 10 to 12 years in this process, is a member of the committee, and also present and someone who's been a long-time leader and advocate for the Green Line Extension, and someone who brings expertise and reason

[Fred Dello Russo]: So it was good to have him there with us, and representing and speaking on behalf of the citizens.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And hopefully as this project moves on, we'll get the best product available for the people of Medford.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Nope.

[Fred Dello Russo]: uh, station, the Medford station, uh, is in the midst of their properties.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yes, thank you, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm generally in favor of this expanded notification, but if I could, Mr. President, through the chair to the solicitor, ask a question regarding the amendment.

[Fred Dello Russo]: My question is this.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It was stated by Councilor Lungo-Koehn that, and I'm sure this is true without a doubt, that we're not seeking to harm the homeowner in this ordinance, but if we put a stipulation on the expansion of the notification to those

[Fred Dello Russo]: projects that require site plan review, i.e., a way of getting at the bigger projects, is that a signaling that we're aiming to harm someone?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Could it be read as that?

[Fred Dello Russo]: So are we targeting someone?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Are we being prejudicial?

[Fred Dello Russo]: So what applies to one thing, should it apply to all?

[Fred Dello Russo]: That's just my question.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yes, Mr. Donaldson.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Uh, we in the public, uh, forum of the, uh, public hearing in those in opposition or in those in favor, Mr. President?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. Starella is in opposition.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Are we now in the portion of the meeting that we can openly discuss and debate?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yes, we are.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The format is before us.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yes, we are.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm on the agenda, it says select an open space discount.

[Fred Dello Russo]: A yes vote would not adopt the open space discount, am I correct?

[Fred Dello Russo]: That is the motion, yay.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yes, thank you, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm generally in favor of this expanded notification, but if I could, Mr. President, through the chair to the solicitor, ask a question regarding the amendment.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Are we being prejudicial?

[Fred Dello Russo]: That's just my question.

[Fred Dello Russo]: You're welcome.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Let's give the clerk the language for the amendments.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Point of order, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yes, Mr. Tillerson.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We in the public forum of the public hearing, are those in opposition or are those in favor, Mr. President?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. Estrella is in opposition.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Are we now in the portion of the meeting that we can openly discuss and debate?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yes, we are.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The format is before us.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yes, we are.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm on the agenda, it says select an open space discount.

[Fred Dello Russo]: A yes vote would not adopt the open space discount, am I correct?

[Fred Dello Russo]: That is the motion, yay.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, we've had, as Councilor Scarpelli mentioned, quite extensive meetings, and we've gotten a lot of answers.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We've gotten a lot of response.

[Fred Dello Russo]: in thoughtful responses to the questions that we've asked on behalf of the citizens regarding this program.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We've also, I think, the representatives of Eversource and their contractor who's going to

[Fred Dello Russo]: execute the project, have listened seriously and intently to the concerns of the council regarding the citizens and what they want regarding traffic, regarding safety.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And we also delved in some of the previously negotiated items from the memorandum of agreement that was etched out between Eversource and

[Fred Dello Russo]: the city administration and various department heads who have expertise in these matters.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And although we were able to make some inroads and renegotiate some of the aspects of the Yalta conference, Mr. President, I'm satisfied as one Councilor to have heard everything satisfactorily that concerns me.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I approve of this project of the grant.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Just briefly on that note as you remember early on in the process 13 years ago that was one of the major concerns that I think people have

[Fred Dello Russo]: who administer projects like this sometimes become, because they live in a world of email communication, sometimes lose track of the fact that not everybody lives on that planet, and that we're dealing with a bigger solar system, and so various modes of communication have to be employed.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And that's why we sent that letter out to the department.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Exactly.

[Fred Dello Russo]: While we're on the suspension, some citizens on Winchester Street would like to address the council regarding a matter that we all received notice on, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: There are some citizens here that would like to speak.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Name and address of the record, please.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I've spoken with Mr. Vola on a couple occasions about this and spoken to the building commissioner, Mr. Moki.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Clearly, upon all the research you've done, Fran,

[Fred Dello Russo]: that the activity that's going on is beyond the scope allowed in the initial variance given to the property owner some 20 plus years ago.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The property owner is not in there.

[Fred Dello Russo]: He leased the property out to a company that's clearly operating way beyond the scope of the restrictions placed on the use of that property.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They are in the process from what the

[Fred Dello Russo]: Building Commissioner has told me they are in the process of finding a new location.

[Fred Dello Russo]: However, he doesn't have an answer on when that's going to be.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And that's what has him concerned the most, because it's too open-ended, and you folks need redress right away.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I just want peace.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Here's what it is at this point.

[Fred Dello Russo]: First of all, I have to share my surprise with J.F.

[Fred Dello Russo]: White.

[Fred Dello Russo]: You rightly mentioned, they're one of the top construction firms in Boston.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They do enormous projects, and you would think, given their history and their success, that they ought to know how to treat people, and they're not treating you well.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And that's sad.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. Mulkey has examined this and cited the property owner for a zoning violation.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So a citation has been issued, all right?

[Fred Dello Russo]: He goes through then a process of responding or appealing, and then they go from there.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Hopefully this will be resolved before then.

[Fred Dello Russo]: He personally met with the,

[Fred Dello Russo]: the manager or whoever's in charge at that location for the construction company.

[Fred Dello Russo]: He explained to them and walked through the whole thing with them where they're in violation.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So they themselves have been put on notice.

[Fred Dello Russo]: He's assured us that the inspectional service director, Mr. Bavuso, is monitoring them on off hours and making spot checks

[Fred Dello Russo]: to survey the property, he wanted you to be aware of that.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And then this is going to have to follow its course.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I have to say that from what I've been told, the property owner is aware of what's going on clearly now and wants to move to get them out of there.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Because he doesn't want them, that reflects poorly, because as you recall, he was a good neighbor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Right.

[Fred Dello Russo]: He probably thought it was going to be a dump spot for trucks and that was it.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Like it's kind of been.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And he was kind of turned key when he operated out there.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The trucks left for the day on their projects.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Never had a problem with him.

[Fred Dello Russo]: No.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So that's where I've been updated on this.

[Fred Dello Russo]: As far as a council resolution, that's up to the councilors if we want to refer this for action and further communication from the building inspector, but that's where he has us today.

[Fred Dello Russo]: All right.

[Fred Dello Russo]: But this is important, too.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This work that you put together is important, because I think it helped us as Councilors clarify the scope to which they're behind, and it also is clear that it's

[Fred Dello Russo]: Um, uh, I know your friend.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I mean, you're not a complainer.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Um, I just want to sleep peacefully.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I don't sleep much as it is, you know, exactly.

[Fred Dello Russo]: You work morning, noon and night.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. Chairman, thank you very much.

[Fred Dello Russo]: If I could, through the chair, say thank you, Commissioner, for bringing this forward and taking the course of action that you're taking in repairing this.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I think it's an appropriate use of this money, and it's going to go a long way in giving a good quality of life to the citizens there.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I know your staff does excellent work in communicating to the neighbors what they're going to encounter in these projects, and I can only foresee this going well.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So thank you very much.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Good luck.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, Mr. Chairman, move approval.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I think it's a wonderful job.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Before we begin, may I just make one brief indication here?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Due to the intervention of this Medford City Council, the comment period was extended with the Secretary of Energy and Environmental Affairs and the Executive Office of Energy and Environmental Affairs regarding the Green Line extension notice of project change.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And so there is an additional

[Fred Dello Russo]: A couple weeks, people have, they should check out the resources and to their new deadline.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And their comments for the environmental impact on the Green Line extension to the parkway may be sent to the MEPA office, EEA number 13886, 100 Cambridge Street, Suite 900, Boston, Massachusetts, 02114.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Councilor Del Rosario.

[Fred Dello Russo]: That the city administration notify the project manager to increase mailing in the Butters neighborhoods.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Um, every presentation we've had on this matter from the office of energy and environment, which has been, they've been excellent presentations.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It's quite clear to me that the Office of Energy and Environment has an agenda.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Their agenda is to get METFIT into municipal aggregation.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And so every presentation we've had has told us how wonderful and awesome and stupendous of an idea this is.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And maybe indeed it is, but we haven't had one credible, balanced presentation of what the negatives are with it, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And a lot of people are concerned about that in the community.

[Fred Dello Russo]: A lot of people think that it would be a good idea that we have, rather than an opt out, an opt in.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So the city offers it, and if people in the community want to do that and get together and do it, then they should opt in.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Now obviously the vendors have something to benefit from by getting the greater portion of the community involved in this.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They have something to gain.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Obviously, always someone has something to gain, and there's nothing wrong with that.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I think this is a stretch in some areas, and I'm particularly concerned, Mr. President, that we'd create a list in advance of people who don't want to participate in this, who don't want to be a member of this.

[Fred Dello Russo]: What does this do to them?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Does this target them in some way?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Who has an access to this list?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Are they going to be contacted and given a spiel to get them to come aboard?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Um, these are questions, uh, serious questions that I have.

[Fred Dello Russo]: These are serious questions that people in the community have, Mr. President, that they need a voice as well.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm going to give them that voice.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And so I do not support this motion, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I think we need to have further discussion on municipal, uh, aggregation.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I think we need to have a credible,

[Fred Dello Russo]: bona fide expert on this matter who is going to give the argument contra.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, while we're nearing the end of the meeting, may I make a motion for suspension of the rules to address a tabled matter?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yes, you may.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Simultaneously.

[Fred Dello Russo]: efficiency, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Move approval, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: If I may, Mr. President, as you're well aware, and I'm sure has been reported to you in why you put this on there,

[Fred Dello Russo]: is that we have certainly a lot of hasty driving there that has resulted in a number of bad situations, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I think that would be a good place for that monitoring.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It serves to quell and remind people of their own behaviors, especially since there's been a citywide adjustment in the speed limit.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Aye.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, I'm delighted to also endorse this project.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Nothing's too good for the people of Medford.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Trick or treat, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, the minutes, the agendas of various boards and commissions are posted on the city website in advance of their meetings.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, the Zoning Board of Appeals has often been presented to me by legal authorities as being a semi-judiciary board.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They make a judicious decisions, uh, regarding alleviating, alleviating, uh, encumbrances or, uh, the actual letter of the law regarding our zoning.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Uh, they can be on great matters or small matters, expanding your front porch, uh, widening your driveway, uh, things of that nature, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Um, and, and one of the things that protects that board,

[Fred Dello Russo]: is that it's free from political influence.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It's free from the influence of city councilors going in there, the mayor telling them what to do.

[Fred Dello Russo]: That's the way it's set up.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And so, Mr. President,

[Fred Dello Russo]: Given the way this was just presented to us by Councilor Lungo-Koehn, I cannot support that because we don't have language to change our ordinance.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So I'm certainly not going to change our ordinance blindly without having a text before us.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Secondly, Mr. President, I wouldn't dare touch this without proper legal advice.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I would think that an officer of the court would know that, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I agree, I wholeheartedly agree that there are some flaws with the way people have access to that meeting room.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It certainly isn't to a standard that people would want, but that needs to be addressed too, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: But to change the, by ordinance, when an independent board can meet,

[Fred Dello Russo]: to make it subject to influence by members of a separate political body, Mr. President, I don't think is good business.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: That's right.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Madam Mayor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Two things I want to mention.

[Fred Dello Russo]: First of all, about the importance of this honor that's bestowed on the citizens of Medford.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It's not only just to recognize the good works that these people have

[Fred Dello Russo]: It's also important because they're held up as examples and as persons.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I think all of us in the city are inspired by the recipients of this honor in many ways throughout the year.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And one in particular has inspired me, and I'm reminded of that inspiration every time, not only I show up to work in the Minor, but every time I walk into this building to do the business of government.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And that's my father, Fred DelRusso, who was honored at City Hall.

[Fred Dello Russo]: in many capacities throughout the years, not only professionally, but as a volunteer, and certainly as a service here in City Hall, as a member of our city council, and as mayor of the city.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So, Dad, thank you for your inspiration.

[Fred Dello Russo]: All of you, and to all the people who are mentioned on this plaque, both here with us, those who weren't able to join us, and those who have gone to God, we thank them.

[Fred Dello Russo]: for their inspiration and for how they have given us a challenge to inspire us to live towards greatness.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So thank you all.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So Dominic Camaro.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Who is like the dean of the College of Cardinals.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We'll see.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Madame Mayor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you for having me.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Happy 80th birthday to Medford City Hall!

[Fred Dello Russo]: Happy 80th birthday Medford City Hall!

[Fred Dello Russo]: Happy 80th birthday Medford City Hall!

[Fred Dello Russo]: You're going to be greeted by the Jingle Bell ladies.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Happy 80th birthday, Medford City Hall!

[Fred Dello Russo]: Happy 80th birthday, Medford City Hall!

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you to the Democratic Committee for giving us this opportunity to speak tonight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It's a pleasure to be here, and it's been a pleasure and an honor to serve you, the people of Medford.

[Fred Dello Russo]: My name is Fred Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm a candidate for re-election to City Council.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I've served on the council for nearly 12 years now, six terms.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm in the end of my sixth term, up for reelection to a seventh.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I am part of a family that's lived in this community for four years.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm the fourth generation of my family to live in Medford.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm the third generation of my family to live in the same house.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I had to buy the house from my father, but it was the house that he had to buy from his father as well.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I'm the third generation of my family to operate a business in Medford.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I love this city.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I've had a lot of opportunity in my life to do other things, but this is where I choose to be.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This is where I choose to serve, to live out my family's heritage of service in this community.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It's something that's shaped who I am as a person.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The only time I lived out of the city was the 12 years I was in religious life.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And that experience too, both academically and spiritually, shaped who I am as a person as well.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And finally,

[Fred Dello Russo]: One of the things that shaped me is doing the work of being a city councilor and serving all of you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It's been a good experience.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It's been challenging at times.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It's been disappointing at times.

[Fred Dello Russo]: But at the end of it all, I'm glad I'm doing it and I want to continue to do it for all of you and for all of us because in that we grow and prosper together.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I've learned a lot over my years on the council.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And one of the greatest issues or lessons I've learned is that we only get things done by working together.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So I could rattle off to you a long list of things that I've accomplished in the 12 years that I've served on this council, and I've had a share in virtually all of them that have happened in this city, though there are some that I perhaps can't put my name to.

[Fred Dello Russo]: However, I've learned that nothing gets done here unless we're working together.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We work together by listening to the community, and I've done that throughout the years, and I continue to do that.

[Fred Dello Russo]: My opinion has changed on issues because of that.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I was a skeptic with the Green Line, and yet I've come along, and I see its benefit.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I was concerned on how it will affect many of the neighbors, but I've worked hard and long on that with many of you, and I've come along on that, and I see its benefit.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I've established good relationships in this community among the greater business community because I'm a businessman, but also because I'm a city councilor, and I see how people who live here, work here, and invest in this community really make it a great place.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I've established great relationships with the people who work in this building.

[Fred Dello Russo]: That's how we get things done, by having solid, good, working relationships with people.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The people who work in this building are committed to you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They are committed to you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They don't come here because it's a great building to work in.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The bathrooms are terrible.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This ceiling was caving in until a couple weeks ago.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And the roof was leaking until a couple months ago.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It's fresh.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It's redone.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We still got a ways to go.

[Fred Dello Russo]: But people are committed to you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The people in public safety are committed to you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I was not afraid to stand alone, to move forward on the bonding of money, to begin the process of the new police station, which has been a long-term goal of mine, which we'll finally see come through.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I've been honored to work with a group of people, one committee that sort of fizzled out in its momentum, through no fault of anybody, I think.

[Fred Dello Russo]: But, and then to work with the new Revive Committee that's working on Medford Square.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This is gonna be the thing that we're on the cusp of moving on.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We're closer than ever before.

[Fred Dello Russo]: There's stuff underway.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We're building a new park in the square.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We have possibly a hotel that's going out right next door.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And plans are being drawn for it.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And it's gonna be part of a revitalization

[Fred Dello Russo]: a renewed program for the revitalization of Medford Square.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm excited to be a part of that and I want to continue to work on that.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I've been an advocate for education and improving it.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It comes from my background as a Benedictine monk.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Who better to know the importance of having a new library in this community than someone that shared in that Benedictine tradition?

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm enthusiastic for that.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Henry.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm enthused to be working towards improvements in all of our squares.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm also looking forward to continue to work on the budget.

[Fred Dello Russo]: You know, this year was in my 12 years on the City Council, this was the best budget that I had the opportunity to work on.

[Fred Dello Russo]: implementation program and ordinance with the assistance of the consultation of the city solicitor and the primary people involved in the leadership of this effort.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, none of them are here to consult us on this.

[Fred Dello Russo]: None of them are here to advise us.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Quite frankly, I am

[Fred Dello Russo]: have an expectation of expertise from them on these matters and questions, and they're not here to present to us.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They've been duly appointed by this body, actually, to act as experts and leaders

[Fred Dello Russo]: in matters regarding the Community Preservation Act in our community.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And in fact, they're meeting tonight at the Department of Public Works Conference Room.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, at this time, the only action I'm able to take, given our lack of input on this matter, and the matter of timing of removing from the table of this matter, is to receive and place on file or to return it to the table.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Citizen Castagnetti wishes to address.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. Hoyer, personal?

[Fred Dello Russo]: I just wanna thank the last speaker for his regular reference to East Medford.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Director of our Community Development Office, Lauren.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Comes in a little glass jar.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Very, very good breakfast.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm hungry.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I believe that any significant renovations must end with the cross scoring.

[Fred Dello Russo]: that's applied into the street as well as the new style of access ramps on the sidewalks with the hobnails in the ramp on the pad and other measures the like.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We can see this demonstrated most clearly with the work that's been done at the intersections of College Avenue and Boston Avenue.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Aye.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you very much.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Economic Development Committee, which takes care of signs.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They've been compliant.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, I want to thank Councilor Knight for his insight on this.

[Fred Dello Russo]: A couple of things were mentioned here tonight, and a couple of things have been sort of brought to light as far as where the community stands on a number of things over this past week, only confirming some of the work that I've been doing for well over a decade.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I think this is a good measure.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We need it in the square and Comcast needs to get this work done.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They're the primary provider here in the city of Medford and people need this service.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm looking at the language in this petition and what it says to me is that the city engineer has finally gone and she's doing something about it.

[Fred Dello Russo]: to decide the extent to which that any of these utility operators are going to have to repair our streets and that they're going to be directed by the office of the engineer.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And if it's curb to curb that the engineer determines is needed, then that's what they're going to provide.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I think we need to have a motion

[Fred Dello Russo]: an amendment to this paper that the City Council understands that the language herein, this petition, for this public hearing and to have this work done, is saying that the City Engineer of the City of Medford will determine how much repair work has to be done to these streets and if it is curb to curb, that Comcast understands that and will fund

[Fred Dello Russo]: the City of Medford and or their contractor to provide that type of repair to the streets for the people of Medford.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Traffic plans, traffic, digging up sales.

[Fred Dello Russo]: 10 of my 12 years on the Council, I've been involved in at least two plans for the revitalization of Medford Square.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We had an unveiling to the general public last week of the redevelopment plan that has been presented.

[Fred Dello Russo]: not engraved in granite, but pretty close by the MAPC, the Metropolitan Area Planning Council, which advises communities in the greater Boston area about planning and development.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We had several private contractors over the years advise the cities.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The plan has had its fits and starts, but we're on the verge of doing something right here.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And one of the things that came out of the meeting this past week

[Fred Dello Russo]: from citizens of Medford, from people who are eager to see us get going, is that we have to shake it up and make ourselves a little uncomfortable to get things going.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And one of the things that this project could enable us to do is see what it's like to tighten things up on Salem Street, to use that type of work as a diversion of traffic so the people of Winchester can stop using

[Fred Dello Russo]: Salem Street, High Street, and Winthrop Street as their private superhighway.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And let them find another way.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Let them go up 93 and get off at Highland Ave, right in their own backyards, rather than going through our backyards and front yards.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So if it's going to tighten things up on Salem Street for some of the people that use it as their cutthroat to Winchester or to Arlington, all the best to them.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Let's look at this, let the engineering department and the community development department

[Fred Dello Russo]: experiment with some of the things that were presented to us in this meeting as part of this plan so we can get a feel for it.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I think the citizens of Medford will benefit.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They're going to benefit from getting this work done.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Hopefully, they'll get in there, get it done, and get lost, and give us the service that we need.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And Mr. President, I'm ready to vote for this and approve for it tonight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: With that amendment.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, I think Councilor Knight is right, if I understood him, in that my amendment was to clarify this language as we're clarifying it.

[Fred Dello Russo]: If we accept this amendment, we've clarified it.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We want, and I think if we can understand a consensus that's come out of our

[Fred Dello Russo]: discussions over the past year or two where this has become such a problem is that the engineer needs to supervise this better, these types of projects better, and hold the contractors accountable.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And it seems to me the way I read this language

[Fred Dello Russo]: here in what she's added is that she's gotten it and she's doing that.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So if the engineer believes that it serves the people of Medford best, that it be curb to curb, then she's going to demand that of these contractors.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Quite frankly,

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm not qualified.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm not an engineer.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm not a construction person.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I can shovel snow.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm pretty good with leaves.

[Fred Dello Russo]: approval, and certainly day-to-day will mandate how the traffic needs to be dealt with, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: If I could, through the chair, ask the petitioner, what is the purpose of this?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Tell us about the type of conduit that you're going to be building.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Is it a contained concrete tunnel?

[Fred Dello Russo]: And are you going to be digging in the road and the sidewalks?

[Fred Dello Russo]: All on the road.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And what kind of wiring is this?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Falco.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Oh, I'm not in the room, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I apologize.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The people on Winchester Street have had the heck beaten out of them for the past five years, and they've been shanghaied every step of the way.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The businesses on Boston Avenue with relation to construction tied into the Green Line and some related developments that are going to capitalize off of the Green Line have suffered tremendously.

[Fred Dello Russo]: On Winchester Street, on the other end from where you're digging, down towards Harvard

[Fred Dello Russo]: Residents were disrupted for two years with work that was done to accommodate the widening of the Harvard Street Bridge and dealing with a lot of the issues there, some of which were promised to be addressed and never were.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I speak of drainage issues in that area.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So beneath the Harvard Street Bridge still floods.

[Fred Dello Russo]: St.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Clement's School, though it's in a transition, still takes on sewage.

[Fred Dello Russo]: an elementary school takes on sewage.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Now, I'm not saying that you are the cause of this.

[Fred Dello Russo]: What I'm saying is that the people who I represent are going to now be faced with another in a series of disruptive construction projects that's going to

[Fred Dello Russo]: challenge their egress in and off of their properties, is going to tie up traffic in a cut-through street that gets people between Harvard Street and Broadway and avoids using the ridiculous powerhouse circle, which has traffic patterns and timing there that is contrary to reason.

[Fred Dello Russo]: What are you folks going to do for the people of Medford on these streets who've had to put up with this over the several years?

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I'm not trying to put you on the spot or make you feel uncomfortable, but the fact of the matter is these people are hurting.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And they need to be assured and in very concrete ways on

[Fred Dello Russo]: How are they going to be treated?

[Fred Dello Russo]: How are they going to be communicated with?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Is just a silly flyer going to be stuck under their doors?

[Fred Dello Russo]: And it's as close as I get to being in the wilderness.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And there's squirrels.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And the rabbits, which have infested Medford.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And the robins chasing the squirrels.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And the starlings chasing the robins.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And the grackles chasing the sparrows.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And so I have a wonderful time enjoying nature.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And in the midst of that,

[Fred Dello Russo]: Traversing my property are many of my dear neighbors who walk their dogs through there and they're lovely and one by one they come but when they intersect they get loud and they start to bark and they get a little out of control and

[Fred Dello Russo]: So I notice that, and as someone who doesn't own a dog, I see that in interaction, whether it's right in front of me when people are just stopping by, or at a distance out on the back road behind my office when people are just crossing and avoiding each other to stay away, to keep the dogs away from each other, and going on opposite sides of the street.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So I know Councilor Scarpelli asked about the

[Fred Dello Russo]: the dogs and the noise.

[Fred Dello Russo]: You explained you're receiving a process on how dogs are allowed to come in and they go into a gated area and they have a little time to decompress and acclimate themselves to a new environment.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I'm sure all the smells of other dogs and the course of nature they have between girl dogs and boy dogs and all that gets some of them wound up.

[Fred Dello Russo]: the issue of noise and how the addition of a new unique noise other than front end loaders backing up with their little beeps and that type of stuff, which the neighborhood is used to and has grown accustomed to, how does adding and interjecting a new and particular noise, which residents there are not accustomed to,

[Fred Dello Russo]: Furthermore, Mr. President, we've had major follow-up meetings regarding Medford Square, and it's been preceded by meetings for over a decade.

[Fred Dello Russo]: May I also point out that we've been handed survey results from the mayor's office, I believe, which I might add are hard to decipher.

[Fred Dello Russo]: But however, based on input I've received from people over quite some time, I'm quite satisfied that there is a grasp on things.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I wish to point out that I do not feel my time has been wasted and I would also take this opportunity to point out and thank what would seem to the untrained ear the accolades I've received from Councilor Marks.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, madam.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The chair recognizes Chairman Marks.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Uh, on that motion chair recognizes councilor night.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I agree.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It's a classy sign proposal.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So on the motion of Councilor Marks that the paper be sent to subcommittee on that motion, Madam Councilor Lungo-Koehn.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, if I could.

[Fred Dello Russo]: If you would like, yes, Mr. Chairman.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Madam Counsel, you're satisfied?

[Fred Dello Russo]: We have the federal holiday coming up next week as well.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Point of information, Councilor Knight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Move the question, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: On that, Chair recognizes Councilor Scarpelli.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So on that motion that the paper go to the subcommittee on, uh, science, business and economic development, all those in favor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Next item on the agenda is a return to the regular order of business on the motion of council night as such all those in favor, all those opposed.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The motion carries 17-five 51 offered by vice president marks.

[Fred Dello Russo]: be resolved that the Eversource Energy Project be discussed on behalf of Metro residents.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I will amend this paper that the director of the Board of Health be invited to attend the meeting and that she prepare herself by researching the impact of these electromagnetic fields.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They can be disruptive to other equipment, power equipment, and personal health devices as well.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I think the vulnerable among us need to be protected and educated in a special way.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They were up for his funeral, uh, this week.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And, uh, he was a decent man.

[Fred Dello Russo]: He had a happy retirement and the city was blessed by his activity here.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I know we're both frequenters of there.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Taki, as he was known by so many people, is a immigrant to the United States, a hardworking man, worked in the restaurant business, opened up his own coffee shop, developed recipes, and produced one of the finest donuts in greater Boston.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Award winning many times, and those of us who have had them know why.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It was not the mayor nor the council that set water rates and fees, but it was that of the Water and Sewer Commission.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I remember that we've discussed in the past 30 days a fee that has been initiated by the Water and Sewer Commission.

[Fred Dello Russo]: President, thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: First, I want to congratulate my colleague for expressing concern for the children back there.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I think that we should follow, quite frankly, I believe we should follow the schema of testing and not scaling back that will allow us to get a proper sample and do proper statistical study of the land back there.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And if we're going to do it, we're going to do it right.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, the people in this neighborhood have been under considerable duress over the whole issue of this Clippership connector, infringements on their property,

[Fred Dello Russo]: infringements on the security, not having an ample opportunity to discuss and explore questions and not being allowed to speak for themselves.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I would rather hear from them about their intentions of pathways and where they go rather than anybody else first.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So therefore they're now faced with additional duress in their living space because they're faced with ancient contaminants that have been there from the days of

[Fred Dello Russo]: masted sailing ships that conducted crimes in our community and around the world.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This soil is clearly contaminated, the extent to which we'll learn further once we do further testing.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So to ameliorate and find a plan of action to take care of this poison in the soil and to bring the residents down there to a peace of mind, I support this paper and move approval.

[Fred Dello Russo]: While we're in suspension, I just want to acknowledge that today,

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I attended last Wednesday night instead of our committee of the whole meeting, I attended a meeting sponsored by the department of transportation on the green line extension and there was there along with the mayor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: and members of our state delegation to express concern by a number of the neighbours and butters to the project.

[Fred Dello Russo]: One of the clear things that's emerged in this latest development of activity along the rail line or the rail corridor is the fact that much of the work proceeded without a point person, a point of contact for the neighbours.

[Fred Dello Russo]: someone who would represent the construction company, the MBTA, the Department of Transportation, to the general public.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We expressed that clearly to the members of the construction team that were present there, the management team from the MBTA, DOT, and the construction people.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And so they got the message clear, not only from the elected officials present,

[Fred Dello Russo]: but also from the neighbours, that they want someone that they can reach out and have open channels of communication where there are problems occurring.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And they are occurring, and there's going to be a significant change, ambient change, to the area as this project continues.

[Fred Dello Russo]: There'll be elimination of virtually all the vegetation all the way up beyond the gymnasium at the corner of College Avenue to accommodate this project in the coming months.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They'll begin the process of widening the rail bed or moving the tracks further to the north to make way for the southern tracks that will be inserted.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And we're going to see the insertion of retaining walls and the beginnings and foundations of sound barriers in the corridor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So they're ready to go.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They're going.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They're moving.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They're doing the prep work.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We can, uh, unless something happens with the funding at this point, uh, we can consider it underway.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And, uh, so, uh, people are going to be affected, uh, and people will need someone to reach out to who was managing the project.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And, um, uh, we made that our priority in that meeting.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Uh, there will be another meeting, I think in a week or so, I forget the exact date, um, here in the council chambers, uh, for the general public of Medford.

[Fred Dello Russo]: to speak on the issue of this green line extension.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I know they're holding one I think this week or next week in Somerville.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So it will be important.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Everything is up on the city's web page and the green line extension web page as far as information and contacts on this.

[Fred Dello Russo]: But I know that a number of people have felt the pressure by being constantly under construction up there for the past several years.

[Fred Dello Russo]: a lot of utility work, and there has been disruption up there.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We want to support the businesses up there.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We want to support you and see that you're served properly up there and don't have to go under any more duress than is necessary.

[Fred Dello Russo]: If I could, through the chair, Mr. President, ask why do you wish to stay open so late?

[Fred Dello Russo]: And if I could, do you offer a delivery service?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Do you have deliveries of pizza?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yes.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, if I might say, uh, in the past, when faced with these requests,

[Fred Dello Russo]: When there's been opposition, those people have made themselves known either by informing myself and other councillors or by making themselves present here at a council meeting.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I can think of one instance where the proprietor of the franchise was quite persistent.

[Fred Dello Russo]: In fact, the first time he petitioned us for extended hours, he arrived here with a dozen pizzas for us.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I did not partake.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And quite frankly, I don't partake of that brand at all, ever.

[Fred Dello Russo]: However, so many of my neighbors were quick to point out, and many of them made themselves present here, and many of them made an effort to contact me at my office to say that they did not want this going on because they did not want these cars speeding through the neighborhood.

[Fred Dello Russo]: As president, I've not been contacted by anybody here.

[Fred Dello Russo]: uh, nor have I seen anybody present to speak in opposition.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I might say that the chairman has made an excellent measure by pointing out that we should have a 90 day review on this and that the, uh, uh, that if the, uh, extended hours of operation are granted, that they'd be granted only to the petitioner and not to a subsequent owner nor towards the property permanently.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: That's one thing that's lacking.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They've already begun construction in work.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They've been clearing brush.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So this has already been underway, there hasn't been a point person on behalf of the project management team.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Projects receive some federal funding too, if I understand correctly, Councilor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And so this is a wonderful measure that will give people in the neighborhood a person that they can discuss their concerns with.

[Fred Dello Russo]: A great many of the people that live in the neighborhood have been very active in this project, and they deserve the best.

[Fred Dello Russo]: that was distributed to the shopkeeps of the neighborhood.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Uh,

[Fred Dello Russo]: I, uh, further like to, I'd like to amend this paper further that the, uh, uh, commissioner of public works update the council, uh, regarding the implementation of additional raised crosswalks.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Uh, the only one I believe that we have in the city, um, uh, on Winthrop street, um, seems to some to do something, but it's, uh, in the three years that it's in place,

[Fred Dello Russo]: In the three years we've been awaiting the other two experimental raised crosswalks, which have yet to arrive, the one existing one has now squished itself out, so to speak, and is just a mere cause for deacceleration as one

[Fred Dello Russo]: achieves rocket speed coming down Winthrop Street so that they can make lights and swerve their way to the South Street Bridge and the Mystic Valley Parkway.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So I'd appreciate an update on what the plans are of the administration.

[Fred Dello Russo]: for implementation of these additional crosswalks which do serve an effect for public safety and to deter speeding where they're maintained, painted and implemented in a pattern that serves the needs of the citizens.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The Councilor also pointed out

[Fred Dello Russo]: the truckings sounds are like airplanes.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I don't know if I agree with that, but I will point out that today, as I observed, the landing pattern of some of the airplanes coming down over the Wellington area, they were so low that if you were to stand on the roof of one of the ninth street condo buildings, I'm sure you could have touched the wheels of the planes as they were being deployed.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, the table records of the meeting of May 9th, 2017 were passed to me for inspection.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I apologize for my absence due to illness at the end of the meeting, uh, due to my allergies.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So I've reviewed those records and moved their approval, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I want to also congratulate you, May.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I want to thank you for your energy, your selfless devotion to the city, your generosity to give of your spirit and your energy and yourself to so many commitments is tough and we thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I hope you keep going and going until you get it right.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So keep at it.

[Fred Dello Russo]: practice makes perfect.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, I just want to point out that this has gone through extensive review and committees and was subject to considerable debate some weeks ago with significant negotiation, second approval.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yes.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, year after year, we have meetings with representatives and delegations from various public service organizations and non-profits who do business in our city.

[Fred Dello Russo]: and who benefit from these grants.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The Office of Community Development goes through great lengths to accommodate and to disperse these funds in a kind manner.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And a great sense of concern is put into this.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So in that light, and I must lament the possibility of diminishment of these fundings, but I move approval to the plan that's been presented to us.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We have two contrasting things, so I just want some clarity, if I could.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Knight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And that, uh, if I could, again, through the chair, that was all agreed to or arrived at with input from the commission and also, uh, the city solicitor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: At Alia?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And so if I could, so then if I remember correctly, we were prepared to have a committee of the whole meeting on those proposals, yet we were asked not to by the commission.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So they had additional additional items that they wanted to put on.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And then once we got those, the sequence events happened that we haven't met.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, I'm not prepared to vote on this tonight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I think we need to sort out what has to be done.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Do that in the Committee of the Whole, at your discretion, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And also have the assistance, the paper was reported out to Committee of the Whole.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I have the assistance of the city solicitor present with us to lend his expertise.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm not at this point asking to table.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I will not support the motion that's before us to vote and approve this.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm not going to support an ordinance change without three readings until we have clear language and the opportunity to come to clarity on this.

[Fred Dello Russo]: with papers before us.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: My assent to the paper before us was under the impression that it was a amendation of the original paper that was in subcommittee as presented and refined by Councilor Knight and presented to us at the sidebar tonight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: which then I hope has taken over the substance in form of the resolution 17-371.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Okay.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Motion by Councilor Dello Russo to suspend the rules.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The purpose of taking 17374 from the table, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: He was already in the midst of his.

[Fred Dello Russo]: My sincerest apologies then, I rescind my request.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And ask that the chairman reconvene the meeting.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor De La Russa.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, I am grateful to have this opportunity to work on this in a concrete way.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I know the subcommittee will get things done, certainly under the leadership of Councilor Knight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I would like to point out, though, that I think it is fairly

[Fred Dello Russo]: almost nightly, maybe every other night, I should say at four in the morning, as I am awakened every time it happens at four in the morning by our dear friends from the Street Sweeper who come by as I live adjacent to a business district.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I have the beautiful sound of the humming of the engine, the whining of the transmission, and the scuffing of the

[Fred Dello Russo]: the brushes that get our streets clean.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yes.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So we can continue to work on this and I think the idea of an ordinance is a good idea.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I think it's a good idea.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, I, too, endorse the candidacy of Roberta.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I laud her for her leadership in this matter.

[Fred Dello Russo]: and her commitment to our community and other matters.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I also particularly point out her patience and willingness to work with people who might not see things the way that she does.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And she's offered great leadership, and I'd like to second her approval.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The President Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, while we're on to suspension, I respectfully request that we take out of order paper 17-374, communications from the mayor regarding the expenditure of monies from free cash

[Fred Dello Russo]: for the updating of our election equipment.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, if I could speak on your behalf, we met in committee of the whole.

[Fred Dello Russo]: To have a presentation from the city clerk

[Fred Dello Russo]: regarding the condition of some of our election equipment and our need to replace it.

[Fred Dello Russo]: That the equipment has become rather old, over 20 years old.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It's difficult to find replacement parts and backup support for the machines, which were once cutting edge.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And now we're on the verge of the clerk, with approval of this, and the commitment to free cash, will assist the process of sending out an RFP and the purchase and examination of some options.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And so we had a detailed discussion in the Committee of the Whole, and it was reported out favorably.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So I'd like to move approval, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So I would ask that as a big paper, as part of this paper, Mr. President may also point out that it was, uh, uh, reported to us that these new

[Fred Dello Russo]: polling machines, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: These new election machines will not be subject to undue interference from foreign powers, whether they be Eastern European or Asian or anywhere else.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, I, too, look forward to hearing more about this from the city administration, members of the Water and Sewer Commission, and the appropriate parties.

[Fred Dello Russo]: who are able to present to us factual information, which I look forward to, and I thank you in advance for your leadership in the matter, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Was that May 2nd, the committee of the whole meeting?

[Fred Dello Russo]: May 2nd is the meeting.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yes.

[Fred Dello Russo]: and respectfully point that out.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And hope that we can take a vote on this or dispose of the matter.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. Marks has withdrawn his motion.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Since the motion to table has been removed, I have a couple of things I'd like to point out and a question through the chair to Ms.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Nunley.

[Fred Dello Russo]: First, I'd like to say that

[Fred Dello Russo]: In recent years, we have not seen such activity, research, seriousness, and sophistication from the Water and Sewer Commission, and we should be grateful for that and for their efforts.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It would be helpful for us to have some information from them regarding what has been presented by my colleague as some sort of service fee, an additional fee.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I can only, uh, speculate at what that might be, uh, uh, directed towards, but, uh, I won't do that out loud.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, I would like to request kindly, because what seems to me is this, the question isn't, uh, it doesn't necessitate, uh, uh, or prevent us from addressing a very pertinent issue, which my colleague has brought up a very serious issue that we need to address as a body.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I agree.

[Fred Dello Russo]: However,

[Fred Dello Russo]: we're dealing with what seems to me to be an accounting issue here.

[Fred Dello Russo]: How do we keep the books?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Um, what style do we use?

[Fred Dello Russo]: I can only imagine that when this water and sewer enterprise account, um, uh, was initiated some many decades ago, uh, that, uh, it was a style of accounting, uh, that might not be in practice, uh, today to have them divided yet they will on the books, uh, appear separately.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The money will just be in one pot, if I understand correctly.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So, through the Chair, to Ms.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Nunley, if I could ask, is there precedent for this?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Is there a new guideline that has come out from the Commonwealth?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Is this a practice that is being adopted by cities and towns who have a water and sewer enterprise account?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you very much, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Uh, I have no problem with this, uh, uh, this, uh, matter before us as far as seeking permission, because we are the authorizing body, obviously, uh, to, uh, address this, uh, matter of bookkeeping, a matter of bookkeeping and account keeping.

[Fred Dello Russo]: it in no ways, in my opinion, abdicates or, uh, minimizes, uh, the matter that my colleague, uh, brought up, which we should have a clear and a significant, uh, uh, conversation with the water and sewing commission about, especially as we're entering the budget season.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So I move approval, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Point of personal interjection.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Uh, it is in the context of those meetings that I've received a comment from people who have, uh, uh, felt as they've told me creeped out by the manner, uh, in which some people have exercised, uh, uh, their rights in that forum, uh, with regards to taping.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And, um, uh, so, uh, I think that that needs to be a matter for discussion and policy.

[Fred Dello Russo]: as well, so we'll talk that out in committee.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Mr. Vice President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Just by way of information, I was under the impression that after our last major power outage, the city suffered some years back, that there was indeed a emergency plan that was under the supervision of the director.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I think we call them emergency management or civil defense had contingencies for these matters.

[Fred Dello Russo]: But it is alarming to note that in housing that caters to largely elderly and disabled and people with critical medical conditions, especially people that need in their domicile machines that generate oxygen for their breathing, to be without the aid of those machines for even a brief period of time

[Fred Dello Russo]: um, might be life threatening and certainly injurious to their health.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Point of information, Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The qualifications and duties of that person have been assumed into the role of the director of health.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, I don't want to seem argumentative in any way, but I think this is a demonstration of a way that legislative process works well.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It works in other bodies this way, both on the local, state, and federal level, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I think in recent years, we've seen a great use and work in subcommittee.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Certainly, Mr. President, in your chairmanship of several subcommittees and also under the chairmanship of Councilor Knight and Councilor Falco and Councilor Scarpelli and Councilor Kern and Councilor Marks and the various roles and chairmanship of subcommittees, we've seen great work in the subcommittees in recent years.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They've not worked this hard, in my estimation, in decades.

[Fred Dello Russo]: You're correct.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So, uh, uh, I, uh, never thought that a Councilor Knight would, uh, um, uh, expect any type of, uh, decision making tonight other than to send these matters to subcommittee.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Um,

[Fred Dello Russo]: Uh, and we've, uh, certainly received, uh, proposals of ordinance, uh, whether it be, uh, through a change in pay grades, uh, loan orders and, uh, any number of proposed ordinances come from the administrative side, uh, to us in the form of an ordinance proposed ordinance that we've, uh, uh, discussed delayed action on, uh, and then, uh, it was, uh, actually, uh, the good measure.

[Fred Dello Russo]: of Councilor Marks who called to all of our attention, and we've held to this over the past two years, that we not pass matters of ordinance in a first reading in wave three.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And this body has stuck to that for two years, which I think is a very good measure and is sound principle in legislation, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So, my remarks aren't to be disagreeable, but only to point out my opinion on the way this process is working, and I think it's working well.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And perhaps if we could amend that, that the city develop a way of communicating with the public on this.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And the difficulty is your power is out.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Those of us who still have flip phones don't have the opportunity to check the internet.

[Fred Dello Russo]: However, in so many people's phones are now battery, if they have phones in their homes still, and not a old fashioned landline, it's hard to communicate out of that.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I will say this, in this last storm, as I put myself to sleep, I was listening to WBZ.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Radio 1030, Dan Ray.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And he had a representative from National Grid on.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And in live time, they kept giving updates through the whole show on what was going on throughout Massachusetts.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And as Towns Power was coming on, they were announcing it.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So they, National Grid, to their credit, had a representative on the most listened to radio station

[Fred Dello Russo]: in the region and was updating people in real time as to, I heard it, the woman was there, she said, at nine o'clock, I think it was a section of Saugus was supposed to come back on.

[Fred Dello Russo]: There was a woman who called who hadn't been listening.

[Fred Dello Russo]: She caught it, she says, I live in Saugus, I got no power, when's it coming on?

[Fred Dello Russo]: And she said, three, two, one, and boom, the ladies' lights came back on.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It was pretty remarkable.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you for this measure, because we do need clearer communication.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We had a major power outage.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It was still warm out, so I think it was at the end of the fall, and South Medford was down.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Half the city was out, really, and it was a complete mess for people.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I too want to congratulate the president on this measure.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I hope that in our meetings and committee that we can also address the issue of taping in committee meetings.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And, um, uh, so I think that that needs to be a matter for discussion and policy.

[Fred Dello Russo]: as well.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So, we'll talk that out in committee.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Mr. Vice President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Councilor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Is that on the document dated March 17th, 2017?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Counsel De La Rosa.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you very much, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And thank you, Mr. Superintendent, for your leadership and your clarity and your foresight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The way I understand this request, it is to get us, as you've presented, into the door and to have items for discussion on the table for us to see what can be funded and what we can receive help with.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm all in favor of a priority list from the school board.

[Fred Dello Russo]: My concern with priority lists from anybody is that they be responsible.

[Fred Dello Russo]: and that they have in mind a larger picture that though this body makes the final decision that we all share a responsibility in.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I approve of this request and I will support it, Mr. Superintendent.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I must say that I hope that when we get into further discussion on how or

[Fred Dello Russo]: in what way some of this money and some of these grants might be directed that we're able to address some of the money that we've spent in the past on the same thing several times.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It seems as though we're chasing leaks in those roofs and replacing them and spending hundreds of thousands of dollars on those roofs in a frequent manner.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I'm concerned about that, and I hope we can get to the bottom of the top of the building.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And so, I think I've said enough, and I think perhaps we've heard enough tonight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And so, I'd like to move approval, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I would, uh, my point was to be, uh, in support of that priority list attachment in so much as it, uh, it doesn't act as a hindrance or as an appropriate in that forum.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I, uh, trust that the superintendent, uh, through the process of meetings, uh, with the authority and, uh, his presence and his negotiating skills won't lead us to be bamboozled.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This is a public forum.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This is a meeting of the Medford City Council.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Second.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Motion's been disposed of.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Excuse me.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, first of all, I want to preface my remarks by saying I approved this project and support of it and I'm in support of it.

[Fred Dello Russo]: However, I urge our friends from the utility company that they need to be

[Fred Dello Russo]: extra sensitive to the neighbors in that area.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They've been under tremendous duress of recent times with construction, repaving, utility work in that vicinity, and it's created great stress and unease with them.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So it's essential that all efforts be made to prevent inconveniences to anybody who's there, whose houses may abut this digging.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We don't want to hold up construction at all, but at the same time, we want to preserve the tranquility of those who reside there and see to it that the street is returned to its pristine condition.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Perhaps it would be helpful that, uh,

[Fred Dello Russo]: When speaking in the chambers, one ought not to put words in another's mouth.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Motion to suspend the rules to take paper off the table.

[Fred Dello Russo]: March 16th, 2017.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Rwy'n rannu sylwadau'r Cyngor a gweld y pwynt y mae'n ei wneud, ond rwy'n credu y bydd angen ymwneud â'r gwasanaethau gwasanaethol ynghylch hynny.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Rwyf hefyd yn ymwneud â'r gwaith y mae'r Cyngor yn gofyn i ni hefyd yma i ddifrif o hynny.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Roedd ychydig o drafodaeth, ac rwy'n gobeithio'r adnodd hwnnw, ond mae'r cyhoeddwyr y ddinas wedi gwneud rhai pwyntiau sylfaenol ynghylch yr hyn rydym yn gallu ei gynhyrchu o'r cyhoedd a'r hyn rydyn ni ddim yn gallu ei wneud.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Ac eto, rwy'n credu, cyn i ni weithio ar hynny, byddai'n ddefnyddiol i ni gael ei gynnwys i ni'n ymwneud â hynny

[Fred Dello Russo]: Rwy'n rannu sylwadau i'r Cyngor am ddatblygu'r llis hwn ac yn gallu ei fod yn y cyhoedd, oherwydd yna gall y bobl ei gael, ac mae'n defnyddio pobl ar gyfer naturiad penodol neu gweithredu sydd ganddyn nhw, ac mae'n gallu iddyn nhw fod yn cael eu hysbysu.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Felly rwy'n cael rhai sylwadau yno.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Felly byddai hynny'n ddwy o'r sylwadau rydw i'n cael

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yn ddiweddaraf, wrth ddweud hynny, rwy'n gobeithio y byddai'r broblem hwn yn ymwneud â'r broblem sy'n ymwneud â'r broblem sy'n ymwneud â'r

[Fred Dello Russo]: ar gyfer un cymdeithas neu sefydliad cymdeithasol yn ein cymdeithas.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mae pobl y tu ôl i Medfyrdd sy'n ymwneud â'r adnoddau sylfaenol, ac rydyn ni'n gallu… un o'r cyfleoedd a oedd wedi'i ddysgu i ni oedd yna dozen o bobl sy'n byw mewn adnoddau cymdeithasol, adnoddau sefydliadol, yn y ddinas Medfyrdd.

[Fred Dello Russo]: mae hynny'n ddiddorol.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Roedden nhw'n byw mewn cysylltiadau cyffredinol, fel roedden nhw'n byw mewn byrthoedd mewn car pulmen, ac roedd hynny'r unig amgylchedd eu bywyd.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mae'n ddiddorol iawn, ddangosol iawn, ac rydw i'n ei ysgrifennu fel cyffredinol.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mae ein cyfrifiadau a'r dyddiadau cymdeithasol ni wedi dod ymlaen o'r teimladau ddiddorol ynglyn â phobl sy'n arwain

[Fred Dello Russo]: y byddwn i'n ymwneud â'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r rhan fwyaf o'r r

[Fred Dello Russo]: confined to one occupation or social subset within our community.

[Fred Dello Russo]: There are people all over Metfit who are in overpopulated apartments and we can, one instance was,

[Fred Dello Russo]: explained to us where there were some dozen people living in a reconfigured two-family, second-floor apartment in the city of Medford.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They were living in virtual cubbyholes, like they were living in births in a Pullman car, and that was their only living space.

[Fred Dello Russo]: primitive.
