[Fred Dello Russo]: While we're on to suspension, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: While we're on to suspension, Mr. President, I respectfully request that we take item number 16-789 from the table for consideration.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, uh, in, uh, the last, uh, year at the end of the year, we had a presentation from, uh, the mayor's office through the city engineer, uh, to discuss and review, uh, matters pertaining to the, uh, Brownfield and West Medford.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yes.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Uh, we had asked, uh, for some, uh, reports from the, uh, city engineer and she provided them to us in our last week's packet.

[Fred Dello Russo]: and we've had them over the weekend in answer to some of the questions that the Councilors had asked in helping them consider their decision with regards to this matter of justice.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, if I could, through the chair, ask the city engineer, are you convinced that this course of action which is being presented to us is the right course of action to take given the options that you're aware of in treating a situation such as this, a site such as this, and given the time that this has gone on,

[Fred Dello Russo]: and hasn't had a lot of action except testing and monitoring.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Where we have a treatment and mitigation plan, are you confident that this is the city's best option to pursue and that this is something for the sake of justice for the residents and property owners over there that we should undertake?

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I notice in the packet that you provided to us that there was a

[Fred Dello Russo]: This, in particular, has been tremendously helpful in urban areas, in densely populated urban areas where there's been great success.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And this, if I understand correctly, again, through the chair, this is helpful for the environment as well.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Not only does it mitigate and clean up this contamination, but the means by which it's done is not invasive to the environment either.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, I move approval.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, uh, thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And through you to a council Falco, thank you, uh, for offering this, uh, resolution again.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Uh, we can also be thankful for Councilor Knight who, uh, has offered similar measures in the past years.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Um, this is a subject that's been discussed by this body over the years.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I know it's been discussed in the administration over the years in that one of the issues that has been weighed back and forth in discussions that I've been a part of was assessing our ability to pay and hire a person at a salary level, or would we be able to get the same type of service from an individual from having a company on retainer.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And that's one of the things I would imagine that has to be weighed by the administration and our able people.

[Fred Dello Russo]: who work in the offices of budget and finance and our comptroller's office.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I don't know what the answer is.

[Fred Dello Russo]: One could be good as another.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And when we look at communities nearby who have full-time traffic engineers working for them, one of the qualities that I've noticed undeniably

[Fred Dello Russo]: within those communities that have a full-time traffic engineer, that they too, in their proximity to Medford and Boston, share many of the same traffic problems and volume issues that we do now without a traffic engineer.

[Fred Dello Russo]: That's not a reason for us not to have one.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I think this person can help coordinate as we move forward in the implementation of the Smart Streets programs

[Fred Dello Russo]: in this city that we're a proud grantee of, that having a person either working with the engineer's office, either on a full-time basis or as a consultancy firm that has us as one of its accounts and who's invested in Medford's well-being, we'd all benefit.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And so I'm grateful and supportive of this measure, and I'd like to second approval, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Dello Russo.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I want to second this motion, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And just remember Councilor Knight that when I was a kid, I sat on Mike Callahan's lap.

[Fred Dello Russo]: He was Santa Claus.

[Fred Dello Russo]: in Marilyn Perica's living room.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I've reviewed the records and to the best of my capabilities, I found them to be free of error and move their approval.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, yes, I need the same clarification.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The resolution seems vague to me, and if I might add that I'm of the opinion that personnel matters regarding specific personnel, as far as our authority in those matters is known.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It's not under our purview, Mr. President, and one would wonder if it could be considered out of order.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Justice for all, we have our tax rate public hearing, 16-768.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Tax hearing, legal notice, notice of public hearing, City of Medford.

[Fred Dello Russo]: A public hearing will be held by the Medford City Council in the Howard F. Alden Memorial Chamber at City Hall, Medford, Mass., on Tuesday, December 13, 2016, at 7 p.m.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The purpose of the hearing is to hear the Board of Assessors on the following items for the purpose of allocation of the fiscal year 2017 property tax.

[Fred Dello Russo]: One, to determine the residential factor to be used for fiscal year 2017.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Two, select an open space discount.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Three, select a residential exemption.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Four, select a small commercial exemption.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Call 781-393-2501 for any aids or accommodations, et cetera.

[Fred Dello Russo]: By order of the Medford City Council, Edward P. Finn, City Clerk, Medford Daily Mercury,

[Fred Dello Russo]: November 28th and November 5th, 2016 chair recognizes Ed O'Neill and Aleesha Nunley.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Ed O'Neill, our assessor, Alicia, our, um, uh, finance director for the city of Medford, uh, to address us on the proceedings.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We've met twice in the past two weeks.

[Fred Dello Russo]: in committee of the whole and report it out favorably to consider the four questions before us.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Just for the public's information,

[Fred Dello Russo]: the council met for over an hour last week and, uh, for 45 minutes, uh, this week with the, uh, assessor and a finance director and review and a consultant last week, the city's hired consultant on these matters, uh, to, uh, review these matters.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Uh, we did, uh, as we, uh, tend to do, um, uh, some significant research and analysis of figures regarding the resident, uh, exception,

[Fred Dello Russo]: uh, exemption issue and, uh, looked at that in, in quite, uh, a bit of detail.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So, uh, if you have anything more for us, uh, Mr. O'Neill, or if you'd, uh, like to have some questions from the Councilors, otherwise the chair will, uh, await a motion.

[Fred Dello Russo]: and also a reported out of the committee report.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Uh, the clerk just pointed out to me, uh, we're asking for a report to come to us, uh, to learn the total amount of tax dollars that are tax deferred.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And those tax dollars are, um, uh, people who are eligible for tax deferment under certain circumstances pointed out in statute.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And so that was part of our committee report and we're awaiting that report, uh, for the future, but it's not, uh,

[Fred Dello Russo]: conditioned upon our deliberations here.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Chair recognizes Vice President Lerner.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Chair awaits a motion.

[Fred Dello Russo]: No.

[Fred Dello Russo]: With the vote of five and the negative two in the affirmative, the motion fails.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Next.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, motion.

[Fred Dello Russo]: On the main motion, Councilor Knight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: One, to determine the residential factor to be used for fiscal year 2010 on the motion of approval by Councilor Knight by selecting the minimum residential factor, a percentage of the total tax levy will be shifted from the residential taxpayer to the commercial, industrial, and personal property taxpayers.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This results in a lower tax rate for the residential properties and a higher tax rate for commercial, industrial, and personal property taxpayers.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Historically, the council has chosen the minimum residential factor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: If this is once again, the council choice, the minimum residential factor is 0.903265.

[Fred Dello Russo]: On the motion for approval on that by Councilor Knight, Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yes.

[Fred Dello Russo]: With a vote of seven in the affirmative, none in the negative, the motion carries.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Two, adopt an open space discount.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This does not apply in the city of Medford, but a no vote is required.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Fred Dello Russo]: No.

[Fred Dello Russo]: With the vote of seven and the negative, the adoption of an open space discount is declined.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Three, adopt a residential exemption.

[Fred Dello Russo]: If adopted, owner-occupied residential properties may receive an exemption

[Fred Dello Russo]: of up to 35% of the average residential value.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This is accomplished by shifting a portion of the tax levy from the owner-occupied residential properties to non-owner-occupied properties.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Since this shift causes a higher residential tax rate, a number of the owner-occupied properties would also see an increase in their tax bills.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This was outlined for us.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And so a no to adopt would be required

[Fred Dello Russo]: to follow our natural course of things.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Fred Dello Russo]: President Dello Russo?

[Fred Dello Russo]: No.

[Fred Dello Russo]: To adopt on that is a seven in the negative, none in the affirmative, no to adopt on 35.

[Fred Dello Russo]: of the average residential value.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And finally, adopt a small commercial exemption.

[Fred Dello Russo]: If adopted, commercial properties, housing, and business employing 10 or less people valued at less than $1 million may receive an exemption of up to 10% of their assessed value.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This is accomplished by shifting a portion of the commercial industrial tax levy from these eligible properties to other commercial indoor industrial properties.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Since the shift causes a higher commercial and industrial tax rate, all commercial industrial not receiving the exemption would see an increase in their tax bills.

[Fred Dello Russo]: As part of this hearing, it is the duty of the Board of Assessors to notify the Council of any excess levy capacity fiscal year 2017.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Excess levy capacity is $96,627.99.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Four, adopt a small commercial exemption.

[Fred Dello Russo]: A no to stay the course as previously charted.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It will be required here.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. Clerk, call the roll.

[Fred Dello Russo]: No.

[Fred Dello Russo]: No.

[Fred Dello Russo]: With a vote of seven in the negative, none in the affirmative.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The adoption of a small commercial exemption is declined.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Therefore, we have completed our tax work for this year.

[Fred Dello Russo]: and members of the Medford City Council, from Stephanie M. Burke, mayor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Reacceptance of a grant from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and the National AL Park Service Land and Water Conservation Fund

[Fred Dello Russo]: for improvements to Riverside Plaza and to appropriate the funds necessary for the implementation of this project.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Dear President Dello Russo and members, esteemed members of the Medford City Council, the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and the National Park Service have awarded reimbursement grant of $250,000 in federal land and water conservation fund assistance to the city for reconstruction of Riverside Plaza to serve its residents.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Acceptance of this federal grant requires that the property remain open to the general public and prohibits any use other than outdoor recreation at the site in perpetuity.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The land must be dedicated to Chapter 45, Section 3.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Conservation of the property is non-recreational use requires that the Parks Board to abide by Article 97 of the Article of Amendment to the state constitution as well as the Federal Land and Water Conservation Fund

[Fred Dello Russo]: project agreement.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Implementation of the project will cost an estimated total of $550,000, and this sum will be appropriated and allocated to the project by the city prior to the execution of the grant agreement.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I respectfully request and recommend that Your Honourable Body adopt the attached resolution to accept the grant and to appropriate the sum of $550,000 for implementation of the project

[Fred Dello Russo]: the Federal Land and Water Conservation Fund grant will reimburse $250,000 on completion of the project.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, motion to waive.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Signature on file, Stephanie M. Burke, Mayor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Carried 16-805.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Offered by Councilor Knight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Whereas Massachusetts Municipal Association

[Fred Dello Russo]: has established a fiscal policy committee to establish a series of best practice recommendations.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And whereas adequate funding of municipal reserve accounts to mitigate budget risks from extraordinary and unforeseen events and maintain fiscal stability over time has been deemed a best practice.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And whereas it is widely recognized that those local governments who have established and funded reserve and stabilization accounts at sufficient levels

[Fred Dello Russo]: have been well served because these reserves allow localities to sustain services in times of economic and fiscal distress and limit the risk from extraordinary and unforeseen occurrences.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And whereas sound policies and practices, along with adequate levels of reserves, can also have positive impact on credit ratings and reduce the cost of borrowing and capital project spending.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And whereas the DOI's Division of Local Services

[Fred Dello Russo]: advises that a good reserve policy will establish target balances for the local stabilization fund and other reserves and will establish a schedule of annual appropriations designed to reach target balances gradually over time.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And whereas the government finance offices associations executive board recommends local governments establish a formal policy on the level of unrestricted fund balance that should be maintained in the general fund.

[Fred Dello Russo]: at a suggested level of no less than two months of general operating fund revenues or expenditures, and that various parts of the fund balance be specified, each of them, for the purpose of working capital, budget stabilization, and responding to extreme events.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Be it therefore resolved that the Medford City Council request the city's administration

[Fred Dello Russo]: to establish a reserve stabilization account and policy for the use or drawing down off reserves and for the replenishment thereof.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Knight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So if Councilor Knight can respond to that.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We have a motion for approval, seconded by Councilor Caraviello.

[Fred Dello Russo]: You are hereby notified by order of the Medford City Council.

[Fred Dello Russo]: on Tuesday, December 6, 2016, on a petition by National Grid of North Andover and Verizon, Incorporated, for permission to locate poles, wires, and fixtures, including the necessary sustaining and protecting fixtures, along and across the following public way, Boston Avenue.

[Fred Dello Russo]: National grid to install approximately 130 feet of two to four inch conduit from existing pole 1981 onto the property of 640 Boston Avenue.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Verizon New England to replace approximately 130 feet of underground conduit from existing jointly owned pole 1981 in a southerly direction to provide a private property at 640 Boston Avenue.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Wherefore, it prays that after due notice and hearing, as provided by law, it be given permission to excavate the public highways and to run and maintain underground electrical conduits together, with such sustaining and protecting fixtures as it may find necessary for the transmission of electricity.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Set underground conduits to be located substantially in accordance with the plan filed herewith.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mark National Grid, Boston Avenue, Plan Number 212,

[Fred Dello Russo]: 58397, and Verizon plan number P2016-1A1WG9F, dated 11-1-2016.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Approved, Chief Engineer.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Upon review of this petition, the work can proceed forward via the following requirements are met.

[Fred Dello Russo]: No city-owned or private utilities or other such structures

[Fred Dello Russo]: are adversely impacted.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The applicant shall ensure that all sewer, water, and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Any disturbed concrete sidewalk panels shall be replaced in kind.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Said panels are already being replaced by the developer's contract.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Asphalt must be replaced by asphalt.

[Fred Dello Russo]: An as-built sketch must be delivered to the developer's contract for its

[Fred Dello Russo]: for incorporation into the overall site as billed to plan.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Before beginning work, the contractor shall notify DIGSAFE and shall obtain applicable permits from the engineering division.

[Fred Dello Russo]: National grid contractor shall utilize the City of Medford regulations and standards as well as for removing all debris related to its work, approve Superintendent Wyeth's call 781393, et cetera, et cetera, Edward P. Finn, City Clerk, Medford.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Acceptance of tax increment financing agreement.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Dear President Dello Russo and members of the Medford City Council, in accordance with the provisions of general law chapter 40, section 59, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approve the attached resolution accepting a tax increment financing agreement between the city of Medford and Bianco Inc.

[Fred Dello Russo]: and Bianco White LLC regarding property located at one

[Fred Dello Russo]: Brainerd Avenue, Medford, Massachusetts.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The purpose of this resolution is to promote economic development.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Sincerely, Signature on Files, Stephanie M. [Fred Dello Russo]: in substantially the form presented herewith to the Metro City Council pursuant to General Law, Chapter 40, Section 59, and to authorize the mayor to take such action as is necessary to implement the TIF.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Cecilia Yawes, Stephanie Annenberg, Mayor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: In our report out, we asked that the mayor consider adjusting this if it was within a sense that would make sense for the city to do.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So I believe there's been an agreement that rather than do this over a 20-year spread, is to do it over 10?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Nicholas Day, be it resolved that the Medford City Council send its sincere condolences to the family of Bernardino Bernie Stabile on his recent passing.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Be it further resolved that an appropriate memorial and dedication be erected by the mayor in recognition of his service to our nation.

[Fred Dello Russo]: If I may, from the chair, Bernie Stabile is a decorated veteran

[Fred Dello Russo]: in our community.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Member of the United States Marine Corps for over 20 years, Bernie entered the Marines during World War II.

[Fred Dello Russo]: He fought his way through the Pacific, earning the Bronze Star Medal and Presidential Unit Citation.

[Fred Dello Russo]: While Bernie was fighting his way through the Pacific, island to island, his brother died on the beaches of Anzio.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Bernie stayed in the Marine Corps.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Bernie served our nation in the Korean War.

[Fred Dello Russo]: He served our nation in the Vietnam War, a war that was tough for everyone to fight in.

[Fred Dello Russo]: No thanks here at home.

[Fred Dello Russo]: When Bernie got out of the military in 1974, he didn't just give up.

[Fred Dello Russo]: He continued to serve our nation.

[Fred Dello Russo]: He was appointed to the United States Secret Service.

[Fred Dello Russo]: He was a leader here in the Boston office.

[Fred Dello Russo]: a legend in the Secret Service nationally.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Generations of men and women who came up in the Secret Service learned from him.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And there wasn't one president of the United States from his time in the Secret Service to the time of his retirement, some several years ago, that he wasn't part of their motorcade or their personal protection.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Bernie is a great American.

[Fred Dello Russo]: and a great citizen of Medford, a humble man, dedicated family man, and I think this community and our nation owes him a debt of gratitude.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So on the motion for approval by Councilor Knight, please join us in a moment of silence.

[Fred Dello Russo]: 16-738 and 16-739 public hearing.

[Fred Dello Russo]: A public hearing will be held by the Medford City Council in the Howard F. Alden Memorial Auditorium, Medford City Hall, 85 George P. Hassett Drive, Medford, Mass., on Tuesday evening, November 15, 2016, at 7 p.m., on a petition by Dom's Motor Service for a special permit pursuant

[Fred Dello Russo]: to chapter 94 zoning ordinances of the city of Medford, section 94-148, use number 37, to operate an automotive repair establishment at 83 Mystic Avenue, Medford, Mass, said site being located in a C2 zoning district.

[Fred Dello Russo]: At the same meeting, Dom's Motor Service will be petitioning for a class four automotive repair license at 83 Mystic Avenue, Medford, Mass.

[Fred Dello Russo]: petition and plans may be seen in the office of the City Clerk, City Hall, Medford Mass.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Further information and any aid or accommodations, contact the City Clerk's office, ordered by the City Council, Edward P. Finn, City Clerk, advertised in Medford Daily Mercury on November 1st and November 8th.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And a public hearing is a very simple process.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It's divided into two parts.

[Fred Dello Russo]: One part for those in favor of the petition, one part for those in opposition.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And in the public hearing process, all we want to do is hear if you are opposed or in favor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And so as we call you forward and you wish to express your opinion of being either in favor or being in opposition, you do so at that proper time.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And then after the public hearing portion is closed,

[Fred Dello Russo]: then we have discussion on the matter.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So I declare the public hearing opened and open it up to those in favor of the petition.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Anybody in favor of presenting yourself to the podium and state so.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Also, Mr. Clerk, while we're in this moment of quiet, please mark present the Vice President, Councilors Falco and Scarpelli.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you very much.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Aye.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Congratulations.

[Fred Dello Russo]: 16-754 offered by Councilor Knight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Whereas the paper entitled Providing Safe Access to Medical Marijuana in the City of Medford is presently under review by the Medford City Council and whereas

[Fred Dello Russo]: On November 8, 2016, the voters of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts approved the passage of referendum question number four, legalizing the retailing of marijuana and its byproducts for recreational purposes.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And whereas, question number four in section 3A1 specifically reads, zoning ordinances or bylaws should not prohibit placing a marijuana establishment which cultivates, manufactures, or sells marijuana or marijuana products in any area with a medicinal marijuana treatment center as registered

[Fred Dello Russo]: to engage in the same type of activity, and whereas with the passage of question four comes a limit on local control over the zoning and licensing of recreational marijuana establishments directly related to the substance and subject matter of the aforementioned paper entitled Providing Safe Access to Medical Marijuana in the City of Medford, be it resolved that the Medford City Council request an opinion from the city solicitor concerning the impact of the passage of question four has on local

[Fred Dello Russo]: control governing the zoning and licensing of medicinal and recreational marijuana establishments and be a further resolved and opinion be provided as to what options are available in order to hold the issuance of any license for this purpose and abeyance until such impact can be determined.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Chair recognizes Councilor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: on the motion for approval by Councilor Knight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Second by Councilor Scarpelli.

[Fred Dello Russo]: All those in favor?

[Fred Dello Russo]: All those opposed?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Motion carries off by Councilor Knight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: 16-755, whereas on September 23rd, 2016, Mayor Burke introduced the paper entitled Home Rule Petition, increasing the number of licenses available for the sale of wine and malt beverages for consideration by the Medford City Council.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And whereas this matter appeared on the November 4th, 2016 council agenda as paper 16-706, and was subsequently disposed of by majority vote of the council to refer to the subcommittee on licensing, whereas this action is duly reflected in the approved minutes of the October 4th, 2016 regular meeting of the city council, be it so ordered, the Medford City Council rescind vote

[Fred Dello Russo]: 16-seven zero six to allow paper to be reintroduced to the council agenda absent of committee report and the subcommittee on licensing council night.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Do I hear a second?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Seconded by Councilor Caraviello.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We need a roll call on this, Mr. Clerk.

[Fred Dello Russo]: All those in favor?

[Fred Dello Russo]: On motion for a roll call.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll to rescind this.

[Fred Dello Russo]: President Donaldson.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yes, with a vote of seven in the affirmative, none in the negative.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The motion passes.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Now, the matter is before us.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This was presented to us in council

[Fred Dello Russo]: uh, on October 4th, uh, with an introductory letter, uh, dated September 18th, uh, from her honor, the mayor, uh, requesting and recommending that our honor body approve the following home rule petition to be sent to the general court to increase the number of licenses available for the sale of wines and malt beverages in the city of Medford.

[Fred Dello Russo]: As you know, the number of such licenses, licenses,

[Fred Dello Russo]: is presently limited by chapter two 10 of the acts of 2008 to 25.

[Fred Dello Russo]: If this home rule petition is approved by the council and later by the general court, it will increase the available number of these licenses in the city of Medford to 40.

[Fred Dello Russo]: There's a motion on the floor to

[Fred Dello Russo]: I have a paper.

[Fred Dello Russo]: 16702 in the hand of the clerk, but on the council's night on the paper, we have Scribner's hour, Mr. President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It's a seven Oh seven Oh, we have seven Oh six.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It should be seven Oh two.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It is.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So on Mr. Clerk, if you would let the agenda record know that it is to be considered a item number 16-seven Oh two that is before us.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Was there a motion?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Move approval on the motion for approval by Councilor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Second, Mr. Knight, seconded by councilor Caraviello.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Uh, Councilor Marks.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This is for a home rule petition process to be started.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Present.

[Fred Dello Russo]: With seven members present, none absent, please join us in rising to salute the flag.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Chair.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Councilor Knight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. President, I'd like to move to suspend the rules, please.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Motion to suspend the rules for what purpose?

[Fred Dello Russo]: Whereas the American Society of Civil Engineering's 2013 report card for America's infrastructure show that more than 1.3 million miles of US roadways

[Fred Dello Russo]: are in poor or mediocre condition, and whereas American motorists average 324 in additional expenses for repairs and operating costs attributable to roadways in poor or mediocre conditions, and whereas the historic trend in municipal roadway maintenance shows that cities allocate limited maintenance budgets based on a reliance of outdated, costly, and time-consuming pavement condition studies

[Fred Dello Russo]: And whereas, the American Road and Transportation Builders Association finds that 12.5% of Massachusetts interstates, expressways, and other major roads are in need of total resurfacing or restructuring.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And whereas, according to the Federal Highway Administration, the overall rating of roadway quality in Massachusetts is designated as fair to mediocre, and that 89% of all roadways in Massachusetts

[Fred Dello Russo]: are maintained by local cities and towns, and that local roads in Massachusetts carry 66% of the total traffic volume, and whereas there is an evident need for the implementation of a pavement inspection and management program in the city of Medford.

[Fred Dello Russo]: street scan incorporated, or any other entity with similar technology to perform a pavement conditions study of Medford's roadways and establish a pavement inspection and management program for the city of Medford.

[Fred Dello Russo]: City of Medford, Massachusetts loan order for City Hall roof facade improvements, municipal facility, be it ordered that the sum of $1,800,000 be and hereby is appointed, appropriated to pay costs of demolishing and reconstructing the roof and facade of Medford City Hall and all pertinences, uh, there too, including the payment of all costs, incidental and related there too,

[Fred Dello Russo]: And that to raise this appropriation, the city treasurer with the approval of the mayor is authorized to borrow to set some under and pursuant to chapter 44, section 7, 3A of the Massachusetts general laws as amended and supplemented or pursuant to any other enabling authority and to issue bonds or notes of the city therefore.

[Fred Dello Russo]: and further order that the city treasurer is authorized to file an application with the Commonwealth of Massachusetts Municipal Finance Oversight Board to qualify under Chapter 44A of the general laws, any and all bonds or notes of the city authorized by this vote or pursuant to any prior vote of the city and in connection therewith to provide such information and execute such documents as the Municipal Finance Oversight Board of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts may require.

[Fred Dello Russo]: To the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council, City Hall, Medford Mass.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Dear Mr. President and City Councilors, I respectfully request and recommend that Your Honorable Body approve the appropriation of certified free cash in the amount of $1,200,000 for the purpose of awarding

[Fred Dello Russo]: the contract to the lowest qualified bidder for the City Hall roof, parapet, and dome.

[Fred Dello Russo]: An additional project, phase two, will be bid in the spring for internal work in the council chambers and external work such as front entrance, doors, et cetera.

[Fred Dello Russo]: As you are aware, this body authorized the study to be performed

[Fred Dello Russo]: by Rousseau Bar in late spring.

[Fred Dello Russo]: They prepared the specifications for this bid, and we are eager to get this project started before the winter settles in.

[Fred Dello Russo]: As you will note, there is a loan order on the agenda to cover the project, as well as the estimate for phase two work.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We hope that you will authorize both appropriations.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And once the loan order takes three readings, we will submit a paper to rescind this vote.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The balance and certified free cash prior to this vote is 8,187,775.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The building commissioner, Paul Moki will be present to answer any questions you may have.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Chair recognizes Mr. Moki to explain this paper.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Chair awaits a motion on the motion of Councilor Knight for approval.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Motion to table by Councilor Marks.

[Fred Dello Russo]: All those in favor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: All those opposed.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Chair's in doubt.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll on the motion to table.

[Fred Dello Russo]: 16-667 offered by Councilor Knight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Whereas, after a decade of consistent decreases in tobacco use by teenagers, the National Youth Tobacco Survey reports that in 2014, overall use of tobacco among youth arose.

[Fred Dello Russo]: exposing dangerous new trends.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And whereas in March of 2015, the Institute of Medicine released a seminal report detailing the potential public health benefits of enacting a nationwide tobacco 21 policy.

[Fred Dello Russo]: concluding a 25% drop in youth smoking initiation, a 12% drop in overall smoking rates, and 16,000 cases of preteen birth and low birth weight averted in the first five years of the policy.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And whereas in July of 2015, the Centers for Disease Control released a study concluding that an astounding 75% of adults favor raising tobacco age to 21, including 70% of current smokers and 65% of those aged 18 to 24.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And whereas from January 2009 to December 2015, 402 smokers from Medford

[Fred Dello Russo]: were referred to smoking cessation programs through Massachusetts Smoking Helpline, yet only 140 of these individuals completed an intake to quit smoking.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Be it so ordered, the legal age for the retail purchase of tobacco products in the City of Medford be raised to the age of 21 years by striking Municipal Ordinance 58-45B1 and replacing it with the following language.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Conditions of permits.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Conditions of permits are as follows.

[Fred Dello Russo]: One, no entity may sell any tobacco products in any of its forms to any person under the age of 21 years or not being his parent or guardian may give any tobacco products in any of its form to any person under the age of 21 years unless said person is 18 years of age and in possession

[Fred Dello Russo]: of a valid military identification card.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Chair recognizes Councilor Knight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Chair recognizes Councilor Caraviello.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Chair recognizes Councilor Falco.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Councilor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Chair recognizes Councilor Marks.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So it will lend to any person under the age of 21 years period.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yes, sir.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: the board at Medford Cooperative Bank and its successor, Brookline Bank, for 42 years, and whereas Mr. McGlynn served as Medford State Representative in the Massachusetts General Court from 1959 to 1975, and whereas Mr. McGlynn served as the Commissioner to the Public Employees Retirement Administration from 1983 to 1997, and whereas Mr. McGlynn was a combat veteran

[Fred Dello Russo]: President Fred Dello Russo and members of the Medford City Council request for approval under General Laws Chapter 30B, Chapter, Paragraph 12B to extend Brown and Caldwell contract.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Dear President and Councilors, I respectfully request the City Council authorized a second extension to Brown and Caldwell's contract

[Fred Dello Russo]: for engineering and consulting services through the completion of remediation services for a period that is as long as necessary to remediate the site and to conduct post-remediation work, including site closure.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Brown and Caldwell was awarded a three-year contract with the city beginning August 2, 2010, ending August 1, 2013 for engineering and consulting services for contaminated municipal sites.

[Fred Dello Russo]: On June 11, 2013,

[Fred Dello Russo]: City Council granted Brown and Caldwell a three-year extension to August 1, 2016, for work at the site at 448 High Street only.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Pursuant to the contract, Brown and Caldwell has, since the completion of the peer review of the May 2013 remedy implementation plan, modified its remediation approach and has advanced the work meeting both Massachusetts Department of Environmental Protection

[Fred Dello Russo]: and Environmental Protection Agency requirements.

[Fred Dello Russo]: At this juncture, the revised phase four remedy implementation plan has been reviewed by MassDEP, and we need to respond to their comments and submit a final plan.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Following completion of the phase four documents, Brown and Caldwell will prepare key procurement documents to aid in the hiring of a remediation contractor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The proposed remediation is anticipated

[Fred Dello Russo]: take approximately two years with monitoring and site closure activities to follow.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I recommend your approval because it would be detrimental to the cleanup effort to change and engineering firms at this time.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Here are my reasons.

[Fred Dello Russo]: One, Brown and Caldwell has been the LSP of record since January, 2009, when the DEP reopened the 448 high street site and issued a notice of responsibility to the city at Alia.

[Fred Dello Russo]: It has fulfilled all the requirements imposed thus far by the 2013 EPA cleanup grant and has developed a productive relationship with EPA relative to this project.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Three, DEP timelines must be met in the implementation of the phase four plan.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Four, it has provided all the investigations, monitoring, and remediation reports to the DEP, including monitoring of the vapor capture and treatment system

[Fred Dello Russo]: at 7 Canal Street.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Five, failure to extend the contract will result in delays in the implementation of the right mediation plan and have a prohibitive impact on the city's ability to meet the DEP deadlines and EPA cleanup grant timelines.

[Fred Dello Russo]: City Engineer Cassandra Koudelikas is present this evening to answer any questions you may have, councillors.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Madam Engineer,

[Fred Dello Russo]: If you could explain this to us.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, uh, Councilor Knight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you, Councilor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Chair awaits a motion.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Motion for approval, Madam Vice President.

[Fred Dello Russo]: We had a motion for approval from Councilor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Curve yellow as yellow as amended.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Seconded by Councilor Knight.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Mr. Clark, please call the roll.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Yes, with a vote of seven in the affirmative, none in the negative, motion passes.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you.

[Fred Dello Russo]: 16-604.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Honorable members of the Metro City Council, from Mayor Stephanie M. Burke,

[Fred Dello Russo]: Amendment to Chapter 14 of the revised ordinances of the City of Medford entitled Mobile Food Truck Ordinance.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Dear President De La Ruzo and honorable members of the Medford City Council, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approve the following amendment to Chapter 14 of the revised ordinances of the City of Medford entitled Mobile Food Truck Ordinance.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This amendment will allow the City to license food trucks in the City of Medford

[Fred Dello Russo]: with appropriate safeguards for public safety, neighborhoods, and also existing businesses.

[Fred Dello Russo]: An ordinance of this nature is overdue as various public gatherings, community and charitable events become more commonplace and varied in our city.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Given that this council may want to have the comfort of additional time to review this amendment and to offer possible changes or additions, this paper may possibly be referred

[Fred Dello Russo]: to a council subcommittee or committee of the whole meeting.

[Fred Dello Russo]: If this occurs, it is my recommendation then to the council that the pilot program that has been permitted mobile food trucks to be at the farmer's market be extended to the following upcoming events while this ordinance is being considered.

[Fred Dello Russo]: The events are Hoops of Hope, August 20th, Mystic River Celebration, September 24th, Harvest Your Energy Festival,

[Fred Dello Russo]: October 1st, Medford Community Day, October 23rd, Medford Family Network, Condon Shell Concert, August 2, 9, and 16.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Thank you for your consideration.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Sincerely yours, signature on file, Stephanie M. Burke, Mayor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Do any of the councillors want me to read the entire ordinance?

[Fred Dello Russo]: On that motion, Mr. Solicitor.

[Fred Dello Russo]: pertaining to accountability of universities and colleges.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Dear Mr. President and members of the Medford City Council, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approve the following amendment to chapter 26 of the revised ordinance of the city of Medford.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This amendment will assist the city to better address the myriad of issues that arrive when students live off campus.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Specifically, it provides a mechanism through which post-secondary schools within the city

[Fred Dello Russo]: will collect and maintain records of their locally residing off campus student population.

[Fred Dello Russo]: This will assist the city to better provide security and regulatory enforcement services for the off campus student population and to the residents of the city in general.

[Fred Dello Russo]: also has the additional burden of finding a way to deal with this, get the graffiti cleaned up.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And for some people, whether they might own a home or a place of business, the cleanup of such an act is also a burden and may not be covered

[Fred Dello Russo]: under their homeowners or business insurance.

[Fred Dello Russo]: If I could, through the chair, Ms.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Rosen,

[Fred Dello Russo]: So you pointed out a way of presenting budget and analyzing how each department finishes out each year, how it spent its money.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And oftentimes when we get to the end of the year, we do so without doing so in that, you know,

[Fred Dello Russo]: Department X has $30,000 left over that it didn't spend, and it's the last week in June.

[Fred Dello Russo]: So we're going to take that money and throw it into Department Y, who overspent $60,000, and hope let's try to find the other 30 somewhere.

[Fred Dello Russo]: Vis-a-vis the whole capital improvement program, which I think is built into our budget as far as our indebtedness,

[Fred Dello Russo]: throughout the S.Y.

[Fred Dello Russo]: debt service each year is budgeted, because we know that's going to be what it is.

[Fred Dello Russo]: How do you think we can then better improve the budget process?

[Fred Dello Russo]: So starting out with the budget, because I sit on a board for the non-profit, and when we go through our annual budget, we do a projection that we know we're going to have this to work with, X. And then we build to that goal.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And part of that goal in the non-profit is an aspect of fundraising for operations.

[Fred Dello Russo]: But nonetheless, we meet that.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I think I've often thought that that might be a more helpful way of doing what we do here, though it's tough because there's so much unknown.

[Fred Dello Russo]: However, I think that sort of a, and we had talked about this as a group, and I'm sure you remember as far as when we've, several years ago, when we got up to the point of this capital improvement program,

[Fred Dello Russo]: that as a council we had envisioned a visioning process that would be collaborative and something that would have open communication, clarity in goals that we then come to agreement on and reach.

[Fred Dello Russo]: I think to a degree, we did that without going through that process, because the way government communicates in Medford isn't what one may describe as healthy.

[Fred Dello Russo]: But we're doing that.

[Fred Dello Russo]: And I think what you're trying to say, or what you are saying, is, well, then let's do that in a healthy, transparent way.

[Fred Dello Russo]: involves participation.
